dimensions.name: Affective Dimension
dimensions.description: Emotional tone and affective responses to collapse awareness (anxiety, hope, denial, anger)
dimensions.theoreticalBasis: Terror Management Theory, Emotional Regulation, Affect Theory

dimensions.name: Cognitive Dimension
dimensions.description: Awareness, beliefs, and mental models about collapse reality
dimensions.theoreticalBasis: Cognitive Dissonance Theory, System Justification, Motivated Reasoning, Risk Perception

dimensions.name: Relational Dimension
dimensions.description: Social identity, group affiliations, and worldview commitments
dimensions.theoreticalBasis: Social Identity Theory, Moral Foundations Theory, Cultural Theory of Risk, Collective Identity

dimensions.name: Temporal Dimension
dimensions.description: Time orientation and future expectations (past/present/future focus)
dimensions.theoreticalBasis: Temporal Psychology, Adaptive Cycle Theory, Eschatology, Future Time Perspective

dimensions.name: Behavioral Dimension
dimensions.description: Agency, coping strategies, and preparedness actions
dimensions.theoreticalBasis: Self-Efficacy Theory, Coping Theory, Behavioral Adaptation, Agency Theory

questions.text: When confronted with evidence of systemic instability (climate data, economic indicators, social unrest), what is your most honest first reaction?
questions.theoreticalFocus: Cognitive Dissonance, System Justification, Denial mechanisms

answers.text: I question the data's reliability or find reasons why it's exaggerated
answers.theoreticalBasis: System Justification Theory - motivated reasoning to defend existing systems

answers.text: I feel a surge of anxiety and urgency to understand the full scope
answers.theoreticalBasis: Terror Management Theory - mortality salience triggers anxiety and threat detection

answers.text: I acknowledge it calmly as part of natural cycles and impermanence
answers.theoreticalBasis: Spiritual Bypass, Mindfulness Theory - transcendence of material threats

answers.text: I see it as confirmation that the system is ready to be dismantled and rebuilt
answers.theoreticalBasis: Critical Theory, Post-Traumatic Growth - crisis as catalyst for transformation

answers.text: I look for the hidden patterns or orchestrated causes behind the instability
answers.theoreticalBasis: Motivated Reasoning, Pattern Recognition, Conspiracy Theory Formation

questions.text: How do you experience mortality or existential threat when considering collapse scenarios?
questions.theoreticalFocus: Terror Management Theory, Existential Psychology, Death Anxiety

answers.text: I deflect or avoid these thoughts - they're too overwhelming
answers.theoreticalBasis: Terror Management - defensive avoidance of mortality salience

answers.text: I feel deep fear and am driven to prepare concretely for survival
answers.theoreticalBasis: Terror Management - active coping through control and preparation

answers.text: Death is natural; my spiritual practice helps me accept impermanence
answers.theoreticalBasis: Existential Acceptance, Buddhist Psychology, Transcendence

answers.text: I've already lived through so much loss that this feels like continuation, not new threat
answers.theoreticalBasis: Post-Traumatic Stress, Trauma Habituation, Chronic Stress Adaptation

answers.text: Mortality awareness motivates me to fight for justice and collective liberation
answers.theoreticalBasis: Terror Management - worldview defense through collective action

questions.text: Which statement best describes your belief about your personal agency in influencing collapse trajectories?
questions.theoreticalFocus: Self-Efficacy Theory, Locus of Control, Agency Theory

answers.text: I have virtually no control - forces are too large and I'm powerless
answers.theoreticalBasis: External Locus of Control, Learned Helplessness

answers.text: I can protect my immediate circle through concrete preparation and skills
answers.theoreticalBasis: Self-Efficacy Theory, Bounded Agency, Risk Mitigation

answers.text: Through collective organizing, we can reshape systems and build alternatives
answers.theoreticalBasis: Collective Action Theory, Social Movement Theory, Collective Efficacy

answers.text: I can influence narratives and how people perceive and respond to collapse
answers.theoreticalBasis: Symbolic Interactionism, Narrative Agency, Framing Theory

answers.text: The system works; I can use existing institutions to maintain stability
answers.theoreticalBasis: System Justification, Status Quo Bias, Institutional Trust

questions.text: What temporal frame dominates your thinking about collapse?
questions.theoreticalFocus: Temporal Psychology, Adaptive Cycle, Future Time Perspective

answers.text: The present moment - all we have is now; future speculation is futile
answers.theoreticalBasis: Present-Time Perspective, Mindfulness, Immediate Gratification

answers.text: Imminent future (5-10 years) - I'm preparing for near-term breakdown
answers.theoreticalBasis: Future Time Perspective, Risk Anticipation, Adaptive Cycle (collapse phase)

answers.text: Long-term future (generations) - I think about legacy and what we pass on
answers.theoreticalBasis: Future Time Perspective, Intergenerational Ethics, Legacy Motivation

answers.text: The past - I reference tradition, wisdom, and what worked before
answers.theoreticalBasis: Past Temporal Orientation, Traditionalism, Historical Consciousness

answers.text: Cyclical time - collapse and renewal are recurring patterns, not linear
answers.theoreticalBasis: Adaptive Cycle Theory, Panarchy, Cyclical Time Perception

questions.text: Which social/ideological group do you feel strongest alignment or accountability toward?
questions.theoreticalFocus: Social Identity Theory, Moral Foundations, Collective Identity

answers.text: My immediate family and close personal network - that's my responsibility
answers.theoreticalBasis: Kinship Theory, Bounded Solidarity, Individualism

answers.text: Progressive/leftist movements fighting for systemic justice and equity
answers.theoreticalBasis: Social Identity Theory, Critical Theory, Collective Action

answers.text: Traditional/religious communities upholding faith and moral order
answers.theoreticalBasis: Moral Foundations (authority, sanctity), Religious Fundamentalism

answers.text: Cultural/ethnic identity groups defending tradition and belonging
answers.theoreticalBasis: Group Threat Theory, Social Dominance, Ethnocentrism

answers.text: No specific group - I operate independently and trust my own judgment
answers.theoreticalBasis: Individualism, Autonomy, Weak Group Affiliation

questions.text: How do you make sense of suffering and injustice in collapse contexts?
questions.theoreticalFocus: Moral Foundations Theory, Just World Theory, Environmental Justice

answers.text: Suffering is often deserved or a natural consequence of poor choices
answers.theoreticalBasis: Just World Hypothesis, Victim Blaming, Meritocracy Belief

answers.text: Suffering is systemic and rooted in exploitation, inequality, and injustice
answers.theoreticalBasis: Environmental Justice, Structural Violence, Critical Theory

answers.text: Suffering is part of spiritual testing or divine plan with higher purpose
answers.theoreticalBasis: Theodicy, Religious Coping, Meaning-Making

answers.text: Suffering is random and meaningless - we just cope as best we can
answers.theoreticalBasis: Existentialism, Nihilism, Absurdism

answers.text: I avoid dwelling on suffering - it's too painful and I can't fix it all
answers.theoreticalBasis: Compassion Fatigue, Defensive Avoidance, Emotional Regulation

questions.text: What is your relationship to mainstream institutions (government, media, corporations)?
questions.theoreticalFocus: System Justification, Institutional Trust, Critical Consciousness

answers.text: I trust them to function reasonably well and maintain order
answers.theoreticalBasis: System Justification Theory, Institutional Trust, Status Quo Bias

answers.text: They're fundamentally corrupt and serve elite interests against the people
answers.theoreticalBasis: Critical Theory, Power Analysis, Structural Critique

answers.text: They're actively conspiring to deceive or control populations
answers.theoreticalBasis: Conspiracy Theory, Paranoid Ideation, Distrust

answers.text: They're tools I can leverage or manipulate for strategic advantage
answers.theoreticalBasis: Rational Choice Theory, Instrumental Rationality, Elite Theory

answers.text: They're largely irrelevant to my life - I've disengaged
answers.theoreticalBasis: Political Disengagement, Marginalization, Exit Strategy

questions.text: When faced with contradictory information about collapse severity, how do you process it?
questions.theoreticalFocus: Cognitive Dissonance, Confirmation Bias, Epistemic Humility

answers.text: I favor information that suggests things aren't as bad as feared
answers.theoreticalBasis: Optimism Bias, Motivated Reasoning, Cognitive Dissonance Reduction

answers.text: I gravitate toward worst-case scenarios - better to be over-prepared
answers.theoreticalBasis: Negativity Bias, Risk Aversion, Precautionary Principle

answers.text: I hold multiple scenarios in mind and stay flexible as evidence evolves
answers.theoreticalBasis: Cognitive Flexibility, Epistemic Humility, Uncertainty Tolerance

answers.text: I trust my intuition and lived experience over abstract data
answers.theoreticalBasis: Experiential Knowledge, Embodied Cognition, Tacit Knowledge

answers.text: I look for patterns connecting disparate pieces that reveal hidden truths
answers.theoreticalBasis: Pattern Recognition, Apophenia, Conspiracy Cognition

questions.text: What emotional stance do you most often inhabit regarding collapse?
questions.theoreticalFocus: Affect Theory, Emotional Regulation, Psychological Resilience

answers.text: Chronic anxiety, fear, or dread about what's coming
answers.theoreticalBasis: Anxiety Disorders, Eco-anxiety, Anticipatory Dread

answers.text: Anger or outrage at injustice and those responsible
answers.theoreticalBasis: Moral Anger, Righteous Indignation, Activist Affect

answers.text: Hope, excitement, or energized anticipation of transformation
answers.theoreticalBasis: Hope Theory, Optimism, Post-Traumatic Growth

answers.text: Calm acceptance or equanimity amid uncertainty
answers.theoreticalBasis: Mindfulness, Acceptance, Emotional Regulation

answers.text: Numbness, fatigue, or emotional exhaustion from constant stress
answers.theoreticalBasis: Burnout, Compassion Fatigue, Emotional Exhaustion

questions.text: If societal collapse accelerated tomorrow, what would be your primary coping strategy?
questions.theoreticalFocus: Coping Theory, Survival Psychology, Behavioral Adaptation

answers.text: Activate my preparations - stockpiles, skills, and survival plans
answers.theoreticalBasis: Problem-Focused Coping, Self-Efficacy, Preemptive Adaptation

answers.text: Form or join collective mutual aid networks and community defense
answers.theoreticalBasis: Collective Coping, Mutual Aid Theory, Community Resilience

answers.text: Hustle and adapt daily - find what works in the new reality
answers.theoreticalBasis: Adaptive Coping, Behavioral Flexibility, Resourcefulness

answers.text: Deepen spiritual practice and maintain inner peace regardless of external chaos
answers.theoreticalBasis: Emotion-Focused Coping, Spiritual Coping, Transcendence

answers.text: I would struggle - I don't have resources or skills to manage that
answers.theoreticalBasis: Avoidant Coping, Learned Helplessness, Low Self-Efficacy

questions.text: How do you use humor, irony, or satire in relation to collapse themes?
questions.theoreticalFocus: Humor Theory, Psychological Resilience, Defense Mechanisms

answers.text: Humor is essential - I cope through jokes, memes, and absurdist takes
answers.theoreticalBasis: Humor as Coping Mechanism, Existential Humor, Psychological Defense

answers.text: I rarely use humor - collapse is too serious for levity
answers.theoreticalBasis: Earnest Engagement, Gravity of Threat, Moral Seriousness

answers.text: Humor helps but I balance it with genuine concern and action
answers.theoreticalBasis: Balanced Coping, Integrated Affect, Pragmatic Optimism

answers.text: I don't engage much with collapse themes at all, humorous or otherwise
answers.theoreticalBasis: Avoidance, Disengagement, Denial

answers.text: I use dark humor to point out hypocrisy and contradictions in the system
answers.theoreticalBasis: Satire, Social Critique, Gallows Humor

questions.text: What is your relationship to traditional knowledge, indigenous wisdom, or ancestral practices?
questions.theoreticalFocus: Deep Ecology, Kincentric Worldview, Cultural Continuity

answers.text: They're central to my worldview - I actively preserve and practice them
answers.theoreticalBasis: Kincentric Ecology, Cultural Continuity, Indigenous Epistemology

answers.text: They have some value but must be integrated with modern science and progress
answers.theoreticalBasis: Integrative Thinking, Pragmatic Eclecticism

answers.text: I'm skeptical - they're often romanticized or not evidence-based
answers.theoreticalBasis: Scientific Skepticism, Modernity, Progress Narrative

answers.text: I don't have access to ancestral traditions - they were disrupted or lost
answers.theoreticalBasis: Cultural Disruption, Marginalization, Historical Trauma

answers.text: I appreciate them aesthetically but they're not practically relevant to my life
answers.theoreticalBasis: Cultural Appropriation, Surface Engagement, Disconnection

questions.text: How do you view the concept of 'progress' and technological advancement?
questions.theoreticalFocus: Progress Narrative, Technological Solutionism, Critical Theory

answers.text: Progress is real and essential - technology and innovation can solve our problems
answers.theoreticalBasis: Technological Solutionism, Modernization Theory, Progress Narrative

answers.text: Progress is a destructive myth that justifies exploitation and extraction
answers.theoreticalBasis: Critical Theory, Decolonial Theory, Anti-Capitalism

answers.text: We've lost something important - earlier times were better in key ways
answers.theoreticalBasis: Traditionalism, Nostalgia, Declension Narrative

answers.text: Progress is context-dependent - some advances help, some harm
answers.theoreticalBasis: Nuanced Thinking, Pragmatism, Complexity

answers.text: Progress is irrelevant - I focus on what works for me right now
answers.theoreticalBasis: Pragmatic Presentism, Survival Focus, Disengagement

questions.text: When you imagine 20 years into the future, what scenario feels most likely?
questions.theoreticalFocus: Future Scenarios, Risk Perception, Adaptive Cycle

answers.text: Continuation with gradual improvement - things will muddle through
answers.theoreticalBasis: Status Quo Bias, Optimism Bias, Normalcy Bias

answers.text: Significant breakdown - scarcity, conflict, and institutional failure
answers.theoreticalBasis: Risk Perception, Catastrophic Thinking, Collapse Theory

answers.text: Transformation through crisis - new paradigm emerging from breakdown
answers.theoreticalBasis: Adaptive Cycle (renewal phase), Post-Traumatic Growth, Hope Theory

answers.text: For some people, worse; for others, better - increasing polarization and inequality
answers.theoreticalBasis: Distributional Justice, Inequality Theory, Realism

answers.text: I don't project that far ahead - too many variables and unknowns
answers.theoreticalBasis: Uncertainty Avoidance, Present Focus, Epistemic Humility

questions.text: How do you process or manage feelings of grief, loss, or despair about ecological destruction?
questions.theoreticalFocus: Ecopsychology, Climate Grief, Emotional Processing

answers.text: I feel it deeply and allow myself to mourn - it's part of staying connected
answers.theoreticalBasis: Active Grieving, Emotional Authenticity, Ecopsychology

answers.text: I channel it into action and fighting back against destruction
answers.theoreticalBasis: Transformative Grief, Activist Coping, Problem-Focused Emotion

answers.text: I find peace in spiritual understanding that nature will endure in some form
answers.theoreticalBasis: Spiritual Coping, Acceptance, Deep Ecology

answers.text: I try not to think about it - it's too overwhelming
answers.theoreticalBasis: Avoidant Coping, Denial, Emotional Suppression

answers.text: I've become numb to it - there's been too much loss for too long
answers.theoreticalBasis: Compassion Fatigue, Psychic Numbing, Trauma Response

questions.text: What is your stance on individual preparedness versus collective action?
questions.theoreticalFocus: Individualism vs. Collectivism, Social Capital, Mutual Aid

answers.text: Individual/family preparedness is paramount - can't rely on others
answers.theoreticalBasis: Individualism, Self-Reliance, Bounded Solidarity

answers.text: Collective action and mutual aid are essential - we survive together or not at all
answers.theoreticalBasis: Collectivism, Mutual Aid Theory, Social Capital

answers.text: Both are important - prepare individually but also build community networks
answers.theoreticalBasis: Balanced Approach, Networked Individualism, Pragmatism

answers.text: Neither matters much - adaptation happens organically in the moment
answers.theoreticalBasis: Improvisation, Spontaneous Organization, Adaptive Emergence

answers.text: I don't have capacity for either - just trying to get through each day
answers.theoreticalBasis: Survival Mode, Resource Scarcity, Chronic Stress

questions.text: How do you relate to power, privilege, and your position in social hierarchies?
questions.theoreticalFocus: Social Dominance Theory, Privilege Awareness, Power Dynamics

answers.text: I'm acutely aware of privilege and actively work to dismantle hierarchies
answers.theoreticalBasis: Critical Consciousness, Anti-Oppression, Reflexivity

answers.text: I use whatever advantages I have - that's just smart strategy
answers.theoreticalBasis: Rational Choice, Social Dominance Orientation, Elite Theory

answers.text: Hierarchies are natural and necessary for order and stability
answers.theoreticalBasis: Social Dominance Theory, Authoritarianism, Hierarchy Justification

answers.text: I'm at the bottom and have been systematically marginalized
answers.theoreticalBasis: Marginalization Theory, Intersectionality, Structural Violence

answers.text: I don't think much about it - I focus on my own path
answers.theoreticalBasis: Meritocracy Belief, Individual Focus, Privilege Blindness

questions.text: What role does spirituality, religion, or meaning-making play in how you process collapse?
questions.theoreticalFocus: Religious Coping, Existential Meaning, Spiritual Bypass

answers.text: Central - my faith or spiritual practice provides framework and comfort
answers.theoreticalBasis: Religious Coping, Spiritual Meaning-Making, Faith as Anchor

answers.text: Important but not exclusive - I integrate spiritual and material understanding
answers.theoreticalBasis: Holistic Worldview, Integration, Eclectic Spirituality

answers.text: Minimal - I rely on reason, science, and material analysis
answers.theoreticalBasis: Secular Worldview, Scientific Rationalism, Materialism

answers.text: I'm skeptical of organized religion but seek personal meaning
answers.theoreticalBasis: Spiritual but not Religious, Meaning-Making, Individualized Faith

answers.text: None - existence feels meaningless or I don't have energy for that reflection
answers.theoreticalBasis: Nihilism, Existential Void, Exhaustion

questions.text: How do you respond to cognitive dissonance between your collapse awareness and daily life participation?
questions.theoreticalFocus: Cognitive Dissonance, Compartmentalization, Psychological Consistency

answers.text: I compartmentalize - keep collapse thoughts separate from daily functioning
answers.theoreticalBasis: Compartmentalization, Dissociation, Adaptive Separation

answers.text: I experience constant tension and guilt about continuing 'normal' life
answers.theoreticalBasis: Cognitive Dissonance, Moral Stress, Psychological Tension

answers.text: I align my life as much as possible with my collapse awareness
answers.theoreticalBasis: Cognitive Consistency, Value-Action Alignment, Integrity

answers.text: I don't experience much dissonance - either not very collapse-aware or not participating much in mainstream life
answers.theoreticalBasis: No Dissonance (low awareness or disengagement)

answers.text: I find absurdity and dark humor in the contradiction
answers.theoreticalBasis: Existential Absurdism, Ironic Distance, Humor as Resolution

questions.text: What is your primary source of resilience or what keeps you going?
questions.theoreticalFocus: Resilience Theory, Psychological Resources, Protective Factors

answers.text: Community, relationships, and solidarity with others
answers.theoreticalBasis: Social Support, Collective Resilience, Relational Strength

answers.text: Hope for transformation and belief that something better can emerge
answers.theoreticalBasis: Hope Theory, Optimism, Post-Traumatic Growth

answers.text: Concrete skills, resources, and self-reliance
answers.theoreticalBasis: Self-Efficacy, Mastery, Resourcefulness

answers.text: Spiritual practice, faith, or connection to something transcendent
answers.theoreticalBasis: Spiritual Resilience, Transcendence, Faith as Resource

answers.text: Honestly, I'm not sure - I just keep moving forward out of habit or necessity
answers.theoreticalBasis: Habitual Persistence, Survival Mode, Minimal Resources

archetypes.name: The Ostrich
archetypes.description: You prefer to keep your head down and avoid dwelling on difficult realities. Life continues, and focusing on the present moment without excessive worry feels most natural to you.
archetypes.extendedDescription: The Ostrich archetype represents a protective mechanismsometimes conscious, sometimes notof filtering out overwhelming information. This isn't necessarily denial, but rather a pragmatic choice to maintain daily functioning.

archetypes.name: The Blissed-Out Yogi
archetypes.description: You maintain inner peace through spiritual practice and perspective. While aware of challenges, you choose to focus on consciousness, presence, and transcending material concerns.
archetypes.extendedDescription: The Yogi archetype embodies a philosophical approach to uncertainty, drawing on contemplative traditions that emphasize acceptance, non-attachment, and the impermanence of all phenomena.

archetypes.name: The Illusionist
archetypes.description: You have a talent for crafting narratives that smooth over rough edges. Whether for self-preservation, social cohesion, or strategic advantage, you shape how others perceive reality.
archetypes.extendedDescription: The Illusionist understands the power of framing, messaging, and perception management. This archetype operates in the space between truth and comfort, wielding influence through story.

archetypes.name: The Normalizer
archetypes.description: You work to maintain stability and continuity. Whether through institutions, routines, or reassurance, you believe in preserving what works and minimizing disruption.
archetypes.extendedDescription: The Normalizer archetype values order, predictability, and gradual change. This pattern serves important social functions, providing ballast against panic and preserving functional systems.

archetypes.name: The Prepper
archetypes.description: You take concrete action to prepare for disruption. Through skills, supplies, and planning, you aim to ensure resilience for yourself and those you care about.
archetypes.extendedDescription: The Prepper archetype embodies agency in the face of uncertainty, channeling awareness into practical preparation. This pattern values self-reliance, foresight, and tangible security.

archetypes.name: The Prophet of Doom
archetypes.description: You see the writing on the wall with clarity that others miss or ignore. Your awareness of systemic fragility comes with urgency and sometimes frustration at collective inaction.
archetypes.extendedDescription: The Prophet archetype carries the burden of foresightseeing trajectories others deny. This pattern combines high awareness with the emotional weight of witnessing slow-motion catastrophe.

archetypes.name: The Alt-Right Collapse Bro
archetypes.description: You combine awareness of systemic fragility with traditional or nationalist values. You see collapse through a lens of strength, identity, and in-group solidarity.
archetypes.extendedDescription: This archetype blends collapse consciousness with specific ideological commitments around hierarchy, tradition, and group identity. It channels anxiety into mobilization around particular visions of order.

archetypes.name: The Evangelical Nationalist
archetypes.description: You interpret current events through the lens of faith and prophecy. Collapse may be judgment, purification, or the necessary precursor to divine restoration.
archetypes.extendedDescription: The Evangelical Nationalist sees collapse as meaningfulpart of a cosmic narrative with spiritual purpose. This archetype finds hope and agency through faith communities and eschatological frameworks.

archetypes.name: The Apocaloptimist
archetypes.description: You see crisis as opportunity. Old systems must break down to make way for something better. You approach uncertainty with energy and creative possibility.
archetypes.extendedDescription: The Apocaloptimist archetype transforms anxiety into anticipation, viewing collapse not as ending but as transition. This pattern combines high awareness with active hope and orientation toward emergence.

archetypes.name: The Trickster
archetypes.description: You navigate uncertainty through humor, chaos, and lateral thinking. When systems fail, you improvise, subvert, and find the absurdity in it all.
archetypes.extendedDescription: The Trickster archetype operates outside conventional rules, using wit and irreverence as survival tools. This pattern sees fluidity where others see fixity, and finds freedom in disruption.

archetypes.name: The Woke Lefty Socialist
archetypes.description: You see collapse as exposing long-standing injustices and systemic failures. Your response centers on solidarity, collective action, and building alternative structures.
archetypes.extendedDescription: This archetype combines structural analysis with moral urgency, viewing collapse through lenses of equity, power, and liberation. It emphasizes collective agency and systemic transformation.

archetypes.name: The Salvager
archetypes.description: You see value in what others discard. Whether material goods, knowledge, or practices, you reclaim, repurpose, and make do with what's available.
archetypes.extendedDescription: The Salvager archetype embodies resourcefulness and adaptive reuse. This pattern finds agency through creative recombination, honoring both pragmatism and sustainability.

archetypes.name: The Sacred Keeper
archetypes.description: You hold and protect what is timelesstraditions, wisdom, practices that connect to something deeper than the current moment. You are a vessel for continuity.
archetypes.extendedDescription: The Sacred Keeper archetype sees collapse as loss but also as reason to preserve. This pattern values lineage, ritual, and the transmission of meaning across time.

archetypes.name: The Everyday Hustler
archetypes.description: You focus on the daily grind, adapting to whatever conditions exist. Whether through multiple jobs, side gigs, or sheer determination, you just keep moving forward.
archetypes.extendedDescription: The Everyday Hustler embodies practical resiliencenot through grand preparation or ideology, but through persistent adaptation and grinding it out day by day.

archetypes.name: The Already Collapsed
archetypes.description: For you, collapse isn't futureit's lived reality. You've experienced ongoing breakdown firsthand and navigate conditions others only imagine or fear.
archetypes.extendedDescription: The Already Collapsed archetype speaks from within the ruins, carrying knowledge that comes only from direct experience of systemic failure and survival at the margins.

archetypes.name: The Extracted
archetypes.description: You havethrough privilege, geography, or circumstancebeen removed from the most immediate impacts. You observe from relative safety, though perhaps with unease.
archetypes.extendedDescription: The Extracted archetype occupies a position of insulation that comes with its own complexitiesawareness of luck or injustice, questions of responsibility, and the fragility of separation.

archetypes.name: The Child Witness
archetypes.description: You observe collapse with fresh eyes, without the frameworks adults use to process or rationalize. You see clearly, but without the tools to fully understand or respond.
archetypes.extendedDescription: The Child Witness archetype represents innocence meeting instabilityawareness without context, perception without power, and the vulnerability of those inheriting uncertain futures.

archetypes.name: The Opportunist Elite
archetypes.description: You see crisis as advantage. With resources and connections, you position yourself to benefit from disruption, viewing instability through the lens of strategic gain.
archetypes.extendedDescription: The Opportunist Elite archetype combines high awareness with instrumental agencynot seeking to prevent collapse but to navigate and exploit it from positions of power.

archetypes.name: The Conspiracy Theorist
archetypes.description: You see patterns and connections that others missor manufacture. Collapse isn't random but orchestrated, and uncovering the hidden truth feels urgent and necessary.
archetypes.extendedDescription: The Conspiracy Theorist archetype seeks explanatory frameworks that restore agency to seemingly chaotic events. This pattern can provide community and meaning, though sometimes at the cost of accuracy.

scoringAlgorithm.description: Multi-dimensional scoring system that calculates both dimensional and archetype alignment

scale.interpretation: Negative values indicate avoidance/low expression; positive values indicate high expression of dimension

dimensions.normalization: Raw dimension scores are summed across all questions, then normalized to [-100, 100] scale for visualization

archetypes.method: Weighted sum of answer scores across all questions
archetypes.tieBreaking: If multiple archetypes have similar scores (within 10% of top score), consider dimensional profile match as secondary criterion
archetypes.threshold: Top 3 archetypes displayed; others shown if within 15% of top score
